boat.construction_details: Larch and cedar on steamed oak ribs, copper fastened, with steel floors

for_sales.sales_text: OFFERS An enthusiast urgently sought to save Devon Maid built as a gentleman’s day boat in 1914. Back of an envelope conservative value of salvageable parts from iron keel upwards, including Beta 20 engine (450hrs), newish sails, s/s rigging and guard rails tops £14,400. Teak covering board, toe rail and other parts removed available to replace. Sadly effects of a stroke prevent me from doing the work myself and the boatbuilder commissioned, having started, has decided to decline without carte blanche for a rebuild with ply deck instead of existing pitch pine planking which is almost wholly good for several more years. This would spoil her in my view and makes the job too expensive as said ill health forces me to part with the boat anyway. It breaks my heart to consider scrapping this beautiful old lady. If you persuade me you can love her as much as I have I’ll virtually give her away with a Beken photograph of Devon Maid taking part in the first Old Gaffers Race of 1959 !

boat.full_description:
Originally a dayboat, 'Devon Maid' had a coachroof added in the 1930s. During the Second World War she was sunk as part of a barrage.

In 1958 she was found sailing in the Alderney Race with no-one on board and was taken to Guernsey by the pilots, one of whom was the father of David Bisson, who bought her in 2009. She took part in the first OGA Solent Race in 1959 under her then owner, Fiona Beale, who then took her to the Helford River, which has been her home port ever since.

Fiona Beale owned her for 50 years.
boat.name: Devon Maid
boat.short_description: Devon Maid was built at Belsize Boatyard on the River Itchen from off-cuts from their steam yachts, mainy larch with some cedar and oak. She raced in the first OGA Solent Race, 1959.
